questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student develops extreme shortness of breath and develops blue fingertips and bilateral crackles after trekking in Ladakh. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Non cardiogenic pulmonary oedema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young individual with acute respiratory distress and bilateral crackles following rapid ascent to high altitude, consider High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which is non-cardiogenic in nature. It is important to distinguish HAPE from other forms of pulmonary edema and respiratory conditions like pneumonia, which have different treatments and implications.
  • ➤ In a young individual with acute respiratory distress and bilateral crackles following rapid ascent to high altitude, consider High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which is non-cardiogenic in nature.
  • ➤ It is important to distinguish HAPE from other forms of pulmonary edema and respiratory conditions like pneumonia, which have different treatments and implications.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with exercise intolerance. On investigation, blood pH is 7.3, Fasting Blood Sugar is 60 mg%, hypertriglyceridemia, ketosis and lactic acidosis are present. The child had hepatomegaly and renomegaly. Biopsy of liver and kidney showed increased glycogen content. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Gierke's disease (GSD Type I) presents with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hypertriglyceridemia, hepatomegaly, and renomegaly due to a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. This results in the accumulation of glycogen and fat in the liver and kidneys, and metabolic abnormalities.
  • ➤ Von Gierke's disease (GSD Type I) presents with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hypertriglyceridemia, hepatomegaly, and renomegaly due to a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • ➤ This results in the accumulation of glycogen and fat in the liver and kidneys, and metabolic abnormalities.

questions.text: In a patient with chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, it is important to understand the role of specific stomach cells. Which factor is primarily associated with enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells of the stomach, and how does it contribute to the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Histamine, which stimulates gastric acid production, potentially exacerbating ulcer symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Gastrin, which promotes mucus production and provides protection against ulcers.

options.label: C
options.text: Pepsinogen, an enzyme involved in protein digestion within the stomach.

options.label: D
options.text: Secretin, a hormone that regulates pancreatic enzyme secretion, influencing digestion.

questions.correct_answer: A. Histamine, which stimulates gastric acid production, potentially exacerbating ulcer symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In managing chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, the histamine from ECL cells helps in stimulating gastric acid production by aggravating ulcer symptoms and increasing mucosal damage. Targeting this pathway with H2 receptor antagonists can be an effective strategy in reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.
  • ➤ In managing chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, the histamine from ECL cells helps in stimulating gastric acid production by aggravating ulcer symptoms and increasing mucosal damage.
  • ➤ Targeting this pathway with H2 receptor antagonists can be an effective strategy in reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature of liver histology in non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibrosis in and around the portal tracts

options.label: B
options.text: Thrombosis of the medium and small portal vein branches

options.label: C
options.text: Non-specific inflammatory cell infiltrates in the portal tracts

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bridging fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key histologic feature of Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis is fibrosis within the portal tracts, without the bridging fibrosis commonly associated with cirrhosis.
  • ➤ The key histologic feature of Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis is fibrosis within the portal tracts, without the bridging fibrosis commonly associated with cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with rheumatic mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation is on therapy for a fast ventricular rate. While on treatment, he develops a regular pulse of 64 beats/min. Which of the following is the probable drug that the patient is receiving?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with atrial fibrillation and underlying heart disease like mitral stenosis, digoxin is effective in controlling the ventricular rate by improving vagal tone and reducing AV nodal conduction, thus potentially regularizing the pulse.
  • ➤ In a patient with atrial fibrillation and underlying heart disease like mitral stenosis, digoxin is effective in controlling the ventricular rate by improving vagal tone and reducing AV nodal conduction, thus potentially regularizing the pulse.

questions.text: In an epidemiological research, a nested case-control study is utilized within an ongoing cohort study. This design is particularly advantageous compared to a standard case-control study in addressing certain methodological challenges. Which of the following issues does a nested case-control study specifically help to avoid?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NESTED CASE CONTROL STUDY
  • ➤ NESTED CASE CONTROL STUDY
  • ➤ Is a hybrid design where ‘a case control study is nested in a cohort study’. Is predominantly a type of Cohort study (due to forward direction). Usefulness limited for studies involving ‘rare diseases AND whose diagnostic tests are very expensive’.
  • ➤ Is a hybrid design where ‘a case control study is nested in a cohort study’.
  • ➤ Is predominantly a type of Cohort study (due to forward direction).
  • ➤ Usefulness limited for studies involving ‘rare diseases AND whose diagnostic tests are very expensive’.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient of nephrotic syndrome presents to the ER with complaints of acute onset of breathlessness after prolonged air travel for 16 hours. On clinical examination, pulse rate is 120/min with BP 130/80mm Hg. SpO2 is 85% and bedside echo shows right ventricular dilation with interventricular septum deviation to the left side. The next step in management is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Unfractionated heparin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with suspected acute pulmonary embolism, the immediate management typically includes the initiation of anticoagulation therapy, with unfractionated heparin being a common choice due to its rapid onset and reversibility, appropriate for emergency settings.
  • ➤ In a patient with suspected acute pulmonary embolism, the immediate management typically includes the initiation of anticoagulation therapy, with unfractionated heparin being a common choice due to its rapid onset and reversibility, appropriate for emergency settings.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male was admitted after a snake bite. Soon after admission, he develops hematuria and deterioration in renal functions. Which enzyme in snake venom causes such effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PLA2 is known for its role in snake venoms, particularly in causing systemic and local effects due to its enzymatic activity on phospholipids, leading to cell membrane disruption, inflammation, and interference with hemostasis, which can contribute to hematuria and renal dysfunction.
  • ➤ PLA2 is known for its role in snake venoms, particularly in causing systemic and local effects due to its enzymatic activity on phospholipids, leading to cell membrane disruption, inflammation, and interference with hemostasis, which can contribute to hematuria and renal dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In managing patients with respiratory distress or during procedures requiring assisted ventilation, the ventral respiratory group of neurons is primarily responsible for forceful expiration.
  • ➤ In managing patients with respiratory distress or during procedures requiring assisted ventilation, the ventral respiratory group of neurons is primarily responsible for forceful expiration.

questions.text: Bilateral ovarian masses are identified on pelvic examination of a 40-year-old woman for which she undergoes total abdominal hysterectomy. Pathologic examination demonstrates papillary carcinoma producing serous fluid. Which of the following tumor markers would be most useful in monitoring for recurrence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CA-125

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CA-125 is the most useful tumor marker for monitoring treatment response and recurrence in patients with epithelial ovarian cancer, such as serous carcinoma.
  • ➤ CA-125 is the most useful tumor marker for monitoring treatment response and recurrence in patients with epithelial ovarian cancer, such as serous carcinoma.

questions.text: Which diuretic could be considered appropriate for combining with ACE inhibitors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rationale for combining hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, with ACE inhibitors in the management of hypertension not only enhances blood pressure control but also balances the potassium-sparing effects of ACE inhibitors with the potassium-excreting properties of thiazide diuretics, minimizing the risk of hyperkalemia.
  • ➤ The rationale for combining hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, with ACE inhibitors in the management of hypertension not only enhances blood pressure control but also balances the potassium-sparing effects of ACE inhibitors with the potassium-excreting properties of thiazide diuretics, minimizing the risk of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A case-control study is designed to investigate the potential association between long-term exposure to electromagnetic fields and the development of glioma. Researchers are determining which statements about the selection of controls and the study design are accurate. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Controls should be selected from a population that has the same potential for glioma as the cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Controls should exclude individuals known to be exposed to high levels of electromagnetic fields at the time of the survey.

options.label: C
options.text: Controls need to be free from glioma but not necessarily from other non-related health conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: The attributable risk of glioma resulting from electromagnetic field exposure may be directly measured.

questions.correct_answer: D. The attributable risk of glioma resulting from electromagnetic field exposure may be directly measured.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AR calculation requires incidence which can be obtained from only a cohort study (Not from a case control study). In a Case Control Study, ‘Cases’ are diseased and ‘Controls’ are healthy. Controls should be similar to Cases in all respects (for ensuring comparability). Cases should be matched with controls for all factors ‘EXCEPT for the (risk) factor under study’ (otherwise the etiological role of risk factor under study, which we are studying, would be eliminated from the study, since both groups are exactly similar in all respects).
  • ➤ AR calculation requires incidence which can be obtained from only a cohort study (Not from a case control study).
  • ➤ In a Case Control Study, ‘Cases’ are diseased and ‘Controls’ are healthy.
  • ➤ Controls should be similar to Cases in all respects (for ensuring comparability).
  • ➤ Cases should be matched with controls for all factors ‘EXCEPT for the (risk) factor under study’ (otherwise the etiological role of risk factor under study, which we are studying, would be eliminated from the study, since both groups are exactly similar in all respects).

questions.text: A man presents with a history of hematemesis of about 500 ml of blood. On examination, the spleen is palpable 5 cms below the left costal margin. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Portal Hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with hematemesis and splenomegaly, portal hypertension should be considered the most likely diagnosis. The condition can lead to the formation of varices, which are prone to rupture and can cause significant gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • ➤ In a patient with hematemesis and splenomegaly, portal hypertension should be considered the most likely diagnosis.
  • ➤ The condition can lead to the formation of varices, which are prone to rupture and can cause significant gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following can be converted to an intermediate of either the citric acid cycle or the urea cycle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aspartate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspartate is unique among amino acids for its ability to be converted into intermediates of both the citric acid cycle (as oxaloacetate) and the urea cycle, linking nitrogen metabolism with energy production pathways. This highlights the interconnectedness of metabolic pathways in the body.
  • ➤ Aspartate is unique among amino acids for its ability to be converted into intermediates of both the citric acid cycle (as oxaloacetate) and the urea cycle, linking nitrogen metabolism with energy production pathways.
  • ➤ This highlights the interconnectedness of metabolic pathways in the body.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques can be used to detect exact localisation of a genetic locus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) is the preferred technique for detecting the exact localization of specific genetic loci on chromosomes, as it allows for direct visualization of fluorescently labelled DNA probes bound to chromosomal DNA.
  • ➤ FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) is the preferred technique for detecting the exact localization of specific genetic loci on chromosomes, as it allows for direct visualization of fluorescently labelled DNA probes bound to chromosomal DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to control tachycardia and palpitations in persons with acute symptoms of hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propranolol is the drug of choice for managing acute cardiovascular symptoms such as tachycardia and palpitations in hyperthyroidism due to its rapid onset of action in blocking sympathetic overactivity induced by high levels of thyroid hormones.
  • ➤ Propranolol is the drug of choice for managing acute cardiovascular symptoms such as tachycardia and palpitations in hyperthyroidism due to its rapid onset of action in blocking sympathetic overactivity induced by high levels of thyroid hormones.

questions.text: In reviewing guidelines for various types of research studies, a medical researcher comes across several standardized reporting guidelines each aimed at improving the quality and transparency of research. Which of the following pairings of guidelines and study types is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GUIDELINES FOR REPORTING MEDICAL RESEARCH
  • ➤ GUIDELINES FOR REPORTING MEDICAL RESEARCH
  • ➤ CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) MOOSE (Meta-analysis Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology) PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses) STROBE (STrengthening the Reporting of Observational studies in Epidemiology) STARD (STAndards for the Reporting of Diagnostic accuracy studies) SPIRIT (Standard Protocol Items: Recommendations for Interventional Trials) CARE guidelines were developed by an international group of experts to increase the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports
  • ➤ CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials)
  • ➤ MOOSE (Meta-analysis Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology)
  • ➤ PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses)
  • ➤ STROBE (STrengthening the Reporting of Observational studies in Epidemiology)
  • ➤ STARD (STAndards for the Reporting of Diagnostic accuracy studies)
  • ➤ SPIRIT (Standard Protocol Items: Recommendations for Interventional Trials)
  • ➤ CARE guidelines were developed by an international group of experts to increase the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with nausea, fever, and jaundice of 5 days duration. The biochemical tests revealed a bilirubin of 6.7 mg/dl, unconjugated bilirubin of 5.0 mg/dl with SGOT/SGPT (AST/ALT) of 1230/900 IU/ml. The serological tests showed the presence of HBsAg IgM, anti HBc and HBeAg. The most likely diagnosis is:

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​ Chronic hepatitis B infection with high infectivity

options.label: B
options.text: Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic hepatitis B infection with low infectivity

options.label: D
options.text: Acute hepatitis B infection with low infectivity

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of IgM HBsAg along with elevated liver enzymes and HBeAg in a patient presenting with symptoms of acute hepatitis is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity. The diagnosis is based on serological profiles, which distinguish acute from chronic infections and determine infectivity based on the presence of HBeAg.
  • ➤ The presence of IgM HBsAg along with elevated liver enzymes and HBeAg in a patient presenting with symptoms of acute hepatitis is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity.
  • ➤ The diagnosis is based on serological profiles, which distinguish acute from chronic infections and determine infectivity based on the presence of HBeAg.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a palpable lump in her neck and symptoms of weight loss, tremors, and palpitations. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender mass in the anterior neck region. Ultrasonography confirms the presence of a thyroid nodule. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the RET gene. This gene mutation is associated with which malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is closely associated with mutations in the RET gene, which plays a crucial role in cell growth and development. These mutations can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and the development of medullary thyroid carcinoma.
  • ➤ Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is closely associated with mutations in the RET gene, which plays a crucial role in cell growth and development.
  • ➤ These mutations can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and the development of medullary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acarbose is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: It acts by inhibiting the enzyme alpha-glucosidase

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases the progression of impaired glucose tolerance to overt diabetes mellitus

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It can cause hypoglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acarbose, an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, effectively reduces postprandial hyperglycemia by delaying carbohydrate digestion and absorption. It does not cause hypoglycemia by itself as it does not influence insulin secretion directly.
  • ➤ Acarbose, an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, effectively reduces postprandial hyperglycemia by delaying carbohydrate digestion and absorption.
  • ➤ It does not cause hypoglycemia by itself as it does not influence insulin secretion directly.

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization's Strategic Advisory Group of Experts (WHO-SAGE) on immunization recommendations for Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination in the 9-14 years age group, what is the correct dosing schedule?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters cannot be obtained by using the following instrument?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Total capacity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spirometry can measure dynamic lung volumes and capacities such as FEV1, FVC, and provide a flow-volume loop, which are essential for the diagnosis and management of respiratory diseases.
  • ➤ The spirometry can measure dynamic lung volumes and capacities such as FEV1, FVC, and provide a flow-volume loop, which are essential for the diagnosis and management of respiratory diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding in lymphoid tissues in individuals with common variable hypogammaglobulinemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Normal B cell count

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) is an immunodeficiency disorder where individuals typically have a normal B cell count in lymphoid tissues, but the B cells have impaired function. This leads to decreased immunoglobulin levels and an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • ➤ Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) is an immunodeficiency disorder where individuals typically have a normal B cell count in lymphoid tissues, but the B cells have impaired function.
  • ➤ This leads to decreased immunoglobulin levels and an increased susceptibility to infections.

questions.text: An epileptic adult man is on levetiracetam 1 g twice a day therapy. He is seizure free for 2 years. Now, he started developing irritability, aggression and liability of mood that is affecting his daily life. What should the doctor do?

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​ Stop the drug and start another antiepileptic

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​​ Continue the medication for another 3 years

questions.correct_answer: B. ​​​​​ Taper the drug over 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When managing side effects of antiepileptic drugs, especially behavioral or psychological side effects, a careful balance must be maintained between controlling seizures and managing adverse effects. Tapering the medication gradually under close medical supervision is often the safest approach to modifying treatment, allowing for adjustment of therapy based on the patient's response in terms of both seizure control and side effect profile.
  • ➤ When managing side effects of antiepileptic drugs, especially behavioral or psychological side effects, a careful balance must be maintained between controlling seizures and managing adverse effects.
  • ➤ Tapering the medication gradually under close medical supervision is often the safest approach to modifying treatment, allowing for adjustment of therapy based on the patient's response in terms of both seizure control and side effect profile.

questions.text: A clinic in a remote area relies on the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) to ensure the usefulness of vaccine during transport and storage. The VVM is an essential component of the cold chain system. What does the effectiveness of the VVM in monitoring the integrity of the vaccine depend on?

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​ Change in the colour of the vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​​ Change in the colour of the monitor

questions.correct_answer: D. ​​​​​ Change in the colour of the monitor
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ WHO grading of VVM : Marker of potency is based on colour changes in VVM: only inner square changes colour, circle always remain blue. VVM has been introduced for almost all vaccines (in NIS) too in India. In VVM, ‘direct relationship exists between the rate of colour change and temperature’, the lower the temperature, the slower the colour change – The higher the temperature, the faster the colour change. Rules for VVM use in India: Rule 1 : If the inner square is lighter than the outer circle, the vaccine may be used– Rule 2 : If the inner square is the same colour as, or darker than, the outer circle, the vaccine must not be used The VVM inner square start point colour is approximately 10% of the outer circle colour. Validation of VVMs : Optical densitometer (for colour density measurement) VVM is best interpreted on a nominal scale: Usable or non-usable
  • ➤ WHO grading of VVM : Marker of potency is based on colour changes in VVM: only inner square changes colour, circle always remain blue.
  • ➤ WHO grading of VVM
  • ➤ VVM has been introduced for almost all vaccines (in NIS) too in India.
  • ➤ In VVM, ‘direct relationship exists between the rate of colour change and temperature’, the lower the temperature, the slower the colour change – The higher the temperature, the faster the colour change.
  • ➤ Rules for VVM use in India: Rule 1 : If the inner square is lighter than the outer circle, the vaccine may be used– Rule 2 : If the inner square is the same colour as, or darker than, the outer circle, the vaccine must not be used
  • ➤ Rules for VVM use in India:
  • ➤ Rule 1 : If the inner square is lighter than the outer circle, the vaccine may be used– Rule 2 : If the inner square is the same colour as, or darker than, the outer circle, the vaccine must not be used
  • ➤ Rule 1 : If the inner square is lighter than the outer circle, the vaccine may be used–
  • ➤ Rule 1
  • ➤ Rule 2 : If the inner square is the same colour as, or darker than, the outer circle, the vaccine must not be used
  • ➤ Rule 2
  • ➤ The VVM inner square start point colour is approximately 10% of the outer circle colour.
  • ➤ Validation of VVMs : Optical densitometer (for colour density measurement)
  • ➤ Validation of VVMs
  • ➤ VVM is best interpreted on a nominal scale: Usable or non-usable

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anemia. Duodenal biopsy shows complete villous atrophy. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antiendomysial antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of malabsorption and duodenal biopsy findings of complete villous atrophy, the most likely diagnosis is celiac disease, and the corresponding serological test would be antiendomysial antibodies, which have a high specificity for this condition.
  • ➤ In the context of malabsorption and duodenal biopsy findings of complete villous atrophy, the most likely diagnosis is celiac disease, and the corresponding serological test would be antiendomysial antibodies, which have a high specificity for this condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with a history of fever and headache and now develops altered sensorium. CT scan shows basal exudates with meningeal enhancement. The CSF is most likely to show:

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​ Lymphocytic pleocytosis, low sugar, low protein

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​​ Polymorphonuclear pleocytosis, normal sugar, high protein

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​​ Lymphocytic pleocytosis, low sugar, high protein

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​​​ Lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal sugar, high protein

questions.correct_answer: C. ​​​​​​ Lymphocytic pleocytosis, low sugar, high protein
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lymphocytic pleocytosis, low sugar, high protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In bacterial meningitis, the CSF analysis often shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose levels due to bacterial consumption, and high protein levels as a result of the inflammatory response. This helps distinguish bacterial meningitis from other types of meningitis such as viral, where glucose levels might be normal or slightly decreased, and protein levels are usually not as elevated.
  • ➤ In bacterial meningitis, the CSF analysis often shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose levels due to bacterial consumption, and high protein levels as a result of the inflammatory response.
  • ➤ This helps distinguish bacterial meningitis from other types of meningitis such as viral, where glucose levels might be normal or slightly decreased, and protein levels are usually not as elevated.

questions.text: Nitrous oxide is contraindicated in patients with pneumothorax, pneumopericardium or intestinal obstruction, because it:

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​​ Permits the use of limited FiO 2 only

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​​​ Causes the expansion of air filled body cavities

questions.correct_answer: D. ​​​​​​ Causes the expansion of air filled body cavities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Causes the expansion of air filled body cavities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nitrous oxide should be avoided in situations where air-filled cavities are present within the body, such as pneumothorax, pneumopericardium, or intestinal obstruction, due to its property of rapidly expanding these spaces. This expansion occurs because nitrous oxide diffuses into the cavities faster than nitrogen can escape, potentially leading to worsening of the condition or complications.
  • ➤ Nitrous oxide should be avoided in situations where air-filled cavities are present within the body, such as pneumothorax, pneumopericardium, or intestinal obstruction, due to its property of rapidly expanding these spaces.
  • ➤ This expansion occurs because nitrous oxide diffuses into the cavities faster than nitrogen can escape, potentially leading to worsening of the condition or complications.

questions.text: An internal medicine doctor is discussing vaccine recommendations for elderly patients during a community health workshop. Given the specific vulnerabilities and health risks associated with older adults, which vaccines are recommended for this age group? Rotavirus vaccine Meningococcal vaccine Diphtheria toxoid Varicella Zoster vaccine
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CDC GUIDELINES FOR IMMUNIZATION OF OLDER PEOPLE
  • ➤ CDC GUIDELINES FOR IMMUNIZATION OF OLDER PEOPLE
  • ➤ Influenza intramuscular inactivated vaccine Pneumococcal vaccine once Tetanus-diphtheria toxoid (Td) booster every 10 years In selected patients aged 60 years or more: Herpes zoster (shingles), Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Meningococcal disease, Varicella, MMR, Yellow fever vaccine (for travellers)
  • ➤ Influenza intramuscular inactivated vaccine
  • ➤ Pneumococcal vaccine once
  • ➤ Tetanus-diphtheria toxoid (Td) booster every 10 years
  • ➤ In selected patients aged 60 years or more: Herpes zoster (shingles), Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Meningococcal disease, Varicella, MMR, Yellow fever vaccine (for travellers)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) since 4 months presents with pain abdomen and cloudy effluent since 1 day. The CAPD fluid total WBC count is 175 cells/mm 3 with 80% neutrophils. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients on CAPD who present with cloudy effluent and abdominal pain, along with an elevated WBC count in the dialysis fluid, particularly with a high percentage of neutrophils, the diagnosis of CAPD-associated peritonitis should be considered. Prompt recognition and treatment of this condition are critical to patient outcomes.
  • ➤ In patients on CAPD who present with cloudy effluent and abdominal pain, along with an elevated WBC count in the dialysis fluid, particularly with a high percentage of neutrophils, the diagnosis of CAPD-associated peritonitis should be considered.
  • ➤ Prompt recognition and treatment of this condition are critical to patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl, who was evaluated for short height was found to have an enlarged pituitary gland. Her T4 was low and TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by low levels of thyroid hormones and elevated TSH levels due to the pituitary gland's attempt to stimulate the underactive thyroid. An enlarged pituitary gland in this context could be a result of hyperplasia from the increased production of TSH.
  • ➤ Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by low levels of thyroid hormones and elevated TSH levels due to the pituitary gland's attempt to stimulate the underactive thyroid.
  • ➤ An enlarged pituitary gland in this context could be a result of hyperplasia from the increased production of TSH.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the indication and mechanism of action of the newly approved drug Zilucoplan?

options.label: A
options.text: Zilucoplan is used for the treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis, acting as a TNF-alpha inhibitor to reduce inflammation and slow disease progression.

options.label: B
options.text: Zilucoplan is approved for the treatment of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), where it acts as a C5 complement inhibitor, preventing hemolysis.

options.label: C
options.text: Zilucoplan is indicated for the management of Myasthenia Gravis, functioning as a complement inhibitor that targets the C5 component, reducing the severity of muscle weakness.

options.label: D
options.text: Zilucoplan is utilized in treating Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, serving as a BTK inhibitor to block cancer cell growth and survival.

questions.correct_answer: C. Zilucoplan is indicated for the management of Myasthenia Gravis, functioning as a complement inhibitor that targets the C5 component, reducing the severity of muscle weakness.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zilucoplan's approval for myasthenia gravis highlights the expanding role of complement inhibitors in treating autoimmune conditions. By targeting the C5 component, zilucoplan effectively reduces the exacerbation of muscle weakness, offering a novel therapeutic approach for patients with this challenging autoimmune disorder.
  • ➤ Zilucoplan's approval for myasthenia gravis highlights the expanding role of complement inhibitors in treating autoimmune conditions.
  • ➤ By targeting the C5 component, zilucoplan effectively reduces the exacerbation of muscle weakness, offering a novel therapeutic approach for patients with this challenging autoimmune disorder.

questions.text: A research team is analyzing the consistency of diagnostic assessments performed by two different clinicians on two separate occasions for the same set of patients. To evaluate the reliability of the diagnoses across these two occasions, they decide to use a statistical method that measures the extent of agreement between the two sets of assessments, correcting for chance agreement. Based on the following information about Kappa coefficient (K), which interpretation best applies if they calculate a Kappa value of 0.45?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ KAPPA COEFFICIENT (K)
  • ➤ KAPPA COEFFICIENT (K)
  • ➤ Indicates the extent of agreement between frequencies of two sets of data collected on two different occasions Formula : K = O-E/(1 – E) Interpretation: 0 = agreement equivalent to chance. 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement. 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement. 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement. 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement. 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement 1 = perfect agreement.
  • ➤ Indicates the extent of agreement between frequencies of two sets of data collected on two different occasions
  • ➤ Formula : K = O-E/(1 – E)
  • ➤ Formula
  • ➤ Interpretation: 0 = agreement equivalent to chance. 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement. 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement. 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement. 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement. 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement 1 = perfect agreement.
  • ➤ Interpretation:
  • ➤ 0 = agreement equivalent to chance. 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement. 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement. 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement. 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement. 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement 1 = perfect agreement.
  • ➤ 0 = agreement equivalent to chance.
  • ➤ 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement.
  • ➤ 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement.
  • ➤ 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement.
  • ➤ 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement.
  • ➤ 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement
  • ➤ 1 = perfect agreement.

questions.text: A 43-year-old white man presents to the emergency department complaining of burning retrosternal chest pain after meals. The pain is relieved by antacids. The patient’s ECG is normal, and x-ray of the chest is remarkable for an 8-cm hiatal hernia. This patient is at risk for developing which of the following types of cancer?

options.label: D
options.text: Non-small cell adenocarcinoma of the lung

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient with chronic GERD and a large hiatal hernia is at increased risk for Barrett's esophagus, which can progress to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Therefore, these patients should be monitored for potential progression to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.
  • ➤ A patient with chronic GERD and a large hiatal hernia is at increased risk for Barrett's esophagus, which can progress to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.
  • ➤ Therefore, these patients should be monitored for potential progression to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl presents with a tibial mass. Histopathological examination reveals a small round cell tumor. Which of the following molecular findings is most likely to be present?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a small round cell tumor in a child's tibia, along with the characteristic translocation involving chromosome 22 (t(11;22)(q24;q12)), suggests a diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma. This translocation results in a fusion gene that contributes to tumor formation.
  • ➤ The presence of a small round cell tumor in a child's tibia, along with the characteristic translocation involving chromosome 22 (t(11;22)(q24;q12)), suggests a diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • ➤ This translocation results in a fusion gene that contributes to tumor formation.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the therapeutic application and mechanism of action of Resmetirom?

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​ Resmetirom is utilized for the treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, functioning as an insulin sensitizer by activating PPAR-gamma receptors to improve glucose utilization.

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​ Resmetirom is used in the management of atrial fibrillation, where it acts as a potassium channel blocker to slow down heart rate and improve heart rhythm.

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​ Resmetirom is indicated for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), acting as a selective thyroid hormone receptor beta (THR-β) agonist to reduce liver fat and fibrosis.

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​ Resmetirom is prescribed for the lowering of high cholesterol, operating as an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor to reduce the production of cholesterol in the liver.

questions.correct_answer: C. ​​​​​ Resmetirom is indicated for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), acting as a selective thyroid hormone receptor beta (THR-β) agonist to reduce liver fat and fibrosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Resmetirom’s mechanism of action as a selective THR-β agonist highlights its novel approach in treating NASH by reducing liver fat and potentially fibrosis through enhanced metabolism and energy expenditure pathways primarily in the liver, making it a targeted treatment for this specific liver condition.
  • ➤ Resmetirom’s mechanism of action as a selective THR-β agonist highlights its novel approach in treating NASH by reducing liver fat and potentially fibrosis through enhanced metabolism and energy expenditure pathways primarily in the liver, making it a targeted treatment for this specific liver condition.

questions.text: A clinical research team is evaluating the efficacy of a new drug for treating chronic pain. They plan to compare the drug's performance with existing pain management protocols using various measures of effectiveness. To ensure the relevance and applicability of their results, which type of validity should the researchers primarily focus on to guarantee that their findings can be generalized to patients outside the study?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ External validity : Assuming causal relationship between 2 variables, defines if our theory can be generalized to the broader population.
  • ➤ External validity : Assuming causal relationship between 2 variables, defines if our theory can be generalized to the broader population.
  • ➤ External validity

questions.text: A young female presents with rhinitis, not subsiding with antihistaminics, along with recurrent hemoptysis & glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is NOT an important differential diagnosis to be considered in the given scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Polyarteritis nodosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of a young female presenting with rhinitis, hemoptysis, and glomerulonephritis, the most likely differential diagnoses include Vasculitis that affect both the respiratory and renal systems, such as Goodpasture syndrome, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and Microscopic polyangiitis. Polyarteritis nodosa typically does not involve the pulmonary system and would not account for hemoptysis, making it less likely in this clinical scenario.
  • ➤ In the context of a young female presenting with rhinitis, hemoptysis, and glomerulonephritis, the most likely differential diagnoses include Vasculitis that affect both the respiratory and renal systems, such as Goodpasture syndrome, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and Microscopic polyangiitis.
  • ➤ Polyarteritis nodosa typically does not involve the pulmonary system and would not account for hemoptysis, making it less likely in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: Which group of drugs is most effective for the healing of Non-Steroidal Anti-inflammatory Drug (NSAID)-induced gastric ulcer:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proton pump inhibitors are the most effective treatment for NSAID-induced gastric ulcers due to their potent acid suppression capabilities. This allows for faster healing of the gastric mucosa and reduces complications associated with these ulcers.
  • ➤ Proton pump inhibitors are the most effective treatment for NSAID-induced gastric ulcers due to their potent acid suppression capabilities.
  • ➤ This allows for faster healing of the gastric mucosa and reduces complications associated with these ulcers.

questions.text: During a workshop on nutrition and energy metabolism for fitness trainers, a dietitian discusses how the body's energy expenditure is affected by the type of food consumed. She explains the concept of the thermic effect of food (TEF), which varies significantly among different macronutrients due to their specific dynamic actions (SDA). What does the 30% thermic effect observed for proteins imply regarding the energy usage from a meal consisting primarily of proteins?

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​ 30% of the calories from protein are used for its metabolic processing, reducing the net caloric gain.

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​​ Only 70% of the calories from protein are absorbed by the body, the rest being lost as heat.

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​​ 30% of the calories from protein are converted directly into body fat.

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​​​ 70% of the calories from protein are expended in the digestion process alone.

questions.correct_answer: A. ​​​​​ 30% of the calories from protein are used for its metabolic processing, reducing the net caloric gain.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Specific dynamic action (SDA) [Thermic effect of food (TEF)/Dietary induced thermogenesis (DIT)] TEF is the amount of energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate due to the cost of processing food for use and storage. TEF is the energy required for digestion, absorption, and disposal of ingested nutrients TEF magnitude depends on the composition of food consumed: Proteins (20-30% of energy consumed > Carbohydrates (5-15%) > Fats (at most 5-15%) A thermic effect of 30% for proteins means that 100 calories of protein only end up as 70 usable calories.
  • ➤ Specific dynamic action (SDA) [Thermic effect of food (TEF)/Dietary induced thermogenesis (DIT)]
  • ➤ TEF is the amount of energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate due to the cost of processing food for use and storage.
  • ➤ TEF is the energy required for digestion, absorption, and disposal of ingested nutrients
  • ➤ TEF magnitude depends on the composition of food consumed: Proteins (20-30% of energy consumed > Carbohydrates (5-15%) > Fats (at most 5-15%)
  • ➤ A thermic effect of 30% for proteins means that 100 calories of protein only end up as 70 usable calories.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is suffering from recurrent abortions and thrombosis of deep veins, thrombocytopenia, and a recent MI. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of recurrent miscarriages and thrombotic events, along with laboratory findings of thrombocytopenia, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome should be considered as a differential diagnosis, and appropriate serological tests should be conducted to confirm the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • ➤ In patients with a history of recurrent miscarriages and thrombotic events, along with laboratory findings of thrombocytopenia, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome should be considered as a differential diagnosis, and appropriate serological tests should be conducted to confirm the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.

questions.text: Low Molecular Weight (LMW) heparin is preferred over unfractionated heparin because:

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​​ LMW heparin directly inhibits thrombin whereas unfractionated heparin acts via activation of antithrombin

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​​ LMW heparins have lesser risk of causing bleeding

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​​ LMW heparin can be given subcutaneously as well as orally

questions.correct_answer: D. ​​​​​​ LMW heparin has consistent bioavailability
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LMW heparin is preferred over unfractionated heparin mainly due to its more predictable pharmacokinetics, which result from its higher bioavailability and longer half-life, allowing for easier dosing without the need for frequent monitoring of aPTT. This makes it especially useful for outpatient anticoagulation therapy.
  • ➤ LMW heparin is preferred over unfractionated heparin mainly due to its more predictable pharmacokinetics, which result from its higher bioavailability and longer half-life, allowing for easier dosing without the need for frequent monitoring of aPTT.
  • ➤ This makes it especially useful for outpatient anticoagulation therapy.

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding the use of malathion during epidemics: Assertion (A): Malathion is used as an Ultra-Low Volume (ULV) during epidemics. Reasoning (R): ULV fogging has a residual effect. Evaluate the correctness of these statements and the relationship between them.

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​ A and R are true statements and R is the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​ A and R are true statements but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​​ A is true but R is false

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​​​ Both A and R are false

questions.correct_answer: C. ​​​​​​ A is true but R is false
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malathion is used as ULV during epidemics using aircraft (esp for Aircraft) in dosage 98% pure malathion 1-2 ounces/acre. ULV has no diluent (hence its more effective than Thermal fogging). ULV has No residual effect (So multiple applications are required).
  • ➤ Malathion is used as ULV during epidemics using aircraft (esp for Aircraft) in dosage 98% pure malathion 1-2 ounces/acre.
  • ➤ ULV has no diluent (hence its more effective than Thermal fogging).
  • ➤ ULV has No residual effect (So multiple applications are required).

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient develops cardiogenic shock following acute myocardial infarction. His urine output decreases in the next few days. He has increased serum urea and creatinine; urine analysis reveals no glucose or protein but numerous hyaline casts are present. After a few days, he develops polyuria and serum creatinine levels fall. Histopathology of renal biopsy in this patient would reveal:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Patchy tubular necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute tubular necrosis is characterized by an initial phase of renal insufficiency following a significant insult (like cardiogenic shock), with subsequent recovery phase demonstrated by polyuria and decreasing creatinine levels. Renal biopsy would typically show patchy necrosis of the tubular epithelial cells.
  • ➤ Acute tubular necrosis is characterized by an initial phase of renal insufficiency following a significant insult (like cardiogenic shock), with subsequent recovery phase demonstrated by polyuria and decreasing creatinine levels.
  • ➤ Renal biopsy would typically show patchy necrosis of the tubular epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-histaminic has very less cholinergic side effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Second-generation antihistamines like loratadine are preferred for patients who want relief from allergic symptoms without the burdensome anticholinergic and sedative side effects often seen with first-generation antihistamines.
  • ➤ Second-generation antihistamines like loratadine are preferred for patients who want relief from allergic symptoms without the burdensome anticholinergic and sedative side effects often seen with first-generation antihistamines.

questions.text: What is the recommended method for the safe disposal of mercury?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MERCURY DISPOSAL
  • ➤ MERCURY DISPOSAL
  • ➤ Dispose mercury as a hazardous waste Never combine it with organic or inorganic waste Never dispose it in sink/drain Dispose off in ‘Recycling units’
  • ➤ Dispose mercury as a hazardous waste
  • ➤ Never combine it with organic or inorganic waste
  • ➤ Never dispose it in sink/drain
  • ➤ Dispose off in ‘Recycling units’

questions.text: Haemoglobin electrophoresis can detect all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemoglobin electrophoresis is a tool that can detect various hemoglobin variants based on their charge differences. It can diagnose conditions like sickle cell disease, HbE disease, and beta thalassemia but has limitations in diagnosing alpha thalassemia trait, which often requires genetic testing due to the normal electrophoresis pattern it can produce.
  • ➤ Hemoglobin electrophoresis is a tool that can detect various hemoglobin variants based on their charge differences.
  • ➤ It can diagnose conditions like sickle cell disease, HbE disease, and beta thalassemia but has limitations in diagnosing alpha thalassemia trait, which often requires genetic testing due to the normal electrophoresis pattern it can produce.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient presents with suspected pneumococcal meningitis. CSF culture is sent for antibiotic sensitivity. Which empirical antibiotic should be given till culture sensitivity result come?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The empirical treatment for suspected pneumococcal meningitis in adults should initially include a third-generation cephalosporin such as cefotaxime or ceftriaxone, combined with vancomycin. This regimen offers the necessary broad-spectrum coverage to address both sensitive and resistant strains of pneumococcus, providing effective management until pathogen-specific sensitivities are available.
  • ➤ The empirical treatment for suspected pneumococcal meningitis in adults should initially include a third-generation cephalosporin such as cefotaxime or ceftriaxone, combined with vancomycin.
  • ➤ This regimen offers the necessary broad-spectrum coverage to address both sensitive and resistant strains of pneumococcus, providing effective management until pathogen-specific sensitivities are available.

questions.text: A clinical dietitian is preparing a presentation on therapeutic diets for a hospital staff training session. One of the topics includes the calorie specifications of FDA-approved high-fat diets used for metabolic health issues. What is the true characteristic of such an FDA-approved high-fat diet regarding its caloric content?

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​ More than 80% of calories should come from fat.

options.label: B
options.text: ​​​​​​ The fat content should exceed 2000 kcal.

options.label: C
options.text: ​​​​​ Total carbohydrates should amount to 400 kcal.

options.label: D
options.text: ​​​​​ Total calorie content should range from 800-1000 kcal.

questions.correct_answer: D. ​​​​​ Total calorie content should range from 800-1000 kcal.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ COMPOSITION OF A HIGH-FAT MEAL (FDA)
  • ➤ COMPOSITION OF A HIGH-FAT MEAL (FDA)
  • ➤ Total Calories : 800-1000 Calories from Protein : 150 kcal Calories from Carbohydrates : 250 kcal Calories from Fat : 500-600 kcal Percent Calories from Fat : >50%
  • ➤ Total Calories : 800-1000
  • ➤ Total Calories
  • ➤ Calories from Protein : 150 kcal
  • ➤ Calories from Protein
  • ➤ Calories from Carbohydrates : 250 kcal
  • ➤ Calories from Carbohydrates
  • ➤ Calories from Fat : 500-600 kcal
  • ➤ Calories from Fat
  • ➤ Percent Calories from Fat : >50%
  • ➤ Percent Calories from Fat

questions.text: Direct Coomb’s test detects the presence of antibodies on the surface of erythrocytes by using:

options.label: A
options.text: ​​​​​ Sensitization of red cells with the antibody globulin

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anti-human globulin antiserum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Direct Coombs test is a laboratory method for detecting antibodies or complement proteins attached to the surface of red blood cells by using anti-human globulin antiserum, which will agglutinate the red blood cells if such antibodies or complement proteins are present.
  • ➤ The Direct Coombs test is a laboratory method for detecting antibodies or complement proteins attached to the surface of red blood cells by using anti-human globulin antiserum, which will agglutinate the red blood cells if such antibodies or complement proteins are present.
